Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.final_reasoning: The available evidence paints a sharply negative picture for 2025 enrollment, especially due to the exceptional, well-documented collapse in new international student arrivals (down 17% overall and ~45% for Indian students), which is unprecedented in the post-pandemic recovery era and is directly attributed to the visa processing breakdown and policy changes. International undergraduates are a small but crucial part of the four-year enrollment pool, and their concentration at four-year institutions—especially among 18-24-year-olds—means the impact will be disproportionately felt in the numerator. Domestically, the rate is also pressured downward by declining high school grads, growing doubts about college value, and tightening institutional finances. While colleges are actively countering these trends through aggressive recruitment, direct admission, and greater aid, these efforts seem insufficient to fully offset the scale of the international decline and broader economic/demographic headwinds. The base rate trend and institutional inertia provide some buoyancy, but the magnitude of the 2025 international shock is likely just enough to tip the rate below the 26.6% threshold. On balance, the probability that Bryan Caplan wins the bet (i.e., the rate is above 26.6%) is now moderately low. I estimate the probability at 35%.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.final_reasoning: The base rate of change in four-year college enrollment for 18–24-year-olds in the U.S. has historically been gradual, with annual declines typically less than 0.5 percentage points. From 2015’s 29.9%, a linear projection to 2025 would expect a rate around 28–28.5%, still above the 26.6% threshold. The 2025 environment is unusually negative: a catastrophic international student collapse (17% drop in new enrollments, especially from key countries like India and China), ongoing domestic demographic shrinkage, and reduced perceived value. However, international undergraduates constitute only about 5–6% of four-year college enrollments, and not all the loss in new international students translates to a proportional drop in the total enrolled population in a single year. Domestic colleges are taking aggressive steps to fill seats, and some international enrollment losses may be deferred rather than lost entirely. The magnitude of the 2025 international shock is likely the largest single-year negative in decades, but given the starting point, the time lag in student pipelines (most undergraduates are multi-year), and institutional countermeasures, it is still somewhat more likely that the 2025 enrollment rate will stay barely above the 26.6% threshold. However, the risk of a sharp break from trend is substantially elevated compared to previous years. I therefore set the probability at 63%, reflecting a modestly confident but far from certain expectation that Caplan will win the bet.

Economics (Signaling Theory).final_reasoning: The catastrophic decline in new international student enrollment in 2025, driven by both policy and administrative failures, is a major negative shock to the numerator of the enrollment rate. While colleges are pulling every institutional lever to offset the loss with domestic students, demographic and attitudinal headwinds make it difficult to fully compensate for a double-digit international drop. The base rate of multi-year change would normally argue for mild inertia—rates don't swing sharply in a single year—but the evidence from 2025 suggests a rare, acute shock. Given the news and base rates, I estimate the probability Bryan Caplan wins his bet at 40%.

higherEducationPolicyAnalysisIpedsEnroll.response: While your estimate (58% probability Caplan wins) rightly emphasizes the inertia of enrollment rates and the mitigating effect of aggressive institutional recruitment, it underestimates both the scale and immediacy of the 2025 international student collapse. The data and news indicate a historic, acute shock: a 17% drop in new international student enrollment, a 44% plunge in Indian arrivals, and widespread disruption in visa processing during the peak enrollment window. These are not gradual background trends but concentrated, system-wide shocks that disproportionately affect the numerator of the rate among 18-24-year-olds in four-year colleges—the exact population the bet targets. While base rates and institutional responses provide some offset, the unique severity and timing of this international contraction, coupled with ongoing domestic demographic and attitudinal headwinds, make a sharp enough drop below the threshold more plausible than your estimate suggests. The claim that many international students are in graduate programs or remain via OPT somewhat blunts the impact, but the undergraduate pipeline is where the greatest loss occurs and will be most visible in the 2025 data. In sum, your argument is sound for typical years, but I believe it gives too much weight to slow-moving trends and institutional resilience, and not enough to the exceptional, acute nature of this year's shocks.

higherEducationPolicyAnalysisPostseconda.response: Your reasoning correctly highlights the severity of the international student enrollment collapse and the role of demographic decline. The denominator (18–24-year-olds) is also shrinking, which helps prop up the rate even as raw enrollment falls. Additionally, while the shock is severe, colleges’ rapid adoption of direct admission, fee waivers, and financial incentives has historically shown some ability to cushion acute drops, especially at less-selective institutions. The probability of such an abrupt, multi-percentage-point decline in a single year, while higher than in any recent year, may still be somewhat less than your sub-40% estimate suggests. A more balanced approach would weight both the unique magnitude of the shock and the historical inertia in these statistics.

You rightly point out that while colleges are using every tool available to offset the international shortfall—aggressive domestic recruitment, relaxed standards—the demographic and attitudinal headwinds make full compensation unlikely. Your emphasis on the base rate for year-to-year changes, and the historical tendency of enrollment rates to move gradually, is important and well-balanced against the rare, acute shock of 2025. Crucially, you note the pipeline effects: while not all international students are lost from the system immediately, the sharp decline in new entrants will have an outsized impact on the 18-24 four-year cohort the bet targets. This approach recognizes both the statistical stickiness of the metric and the plausibility of a sharp enough drop to breach the threshold. Your 40% probability for Caplan winning strikes a reasonable balance between base-rate inertia and the magnitude of current shocks, and your argument helps set a sensible midpoint in the debate.

economicsSignalingTheory.response: Your reasoning accurately grasps both the inertia of enrollment rates and the exceptional nature of 2025's shocks. By invoking Tinto's integration model, you highlight how structural disruptions (like the visa crisis) and negative perceptions have lasting impacts on student flows, not just one-off dips. You correctly recognize that, while the inertia of higher education systems typically prevents sharp annual drops, the confluence of international and domestic shocks in 2025 is likely to have outsized, immediate effects—especially among the very population (18-24-year-old undergraduates) relevant to this bet. Your estimate (35%) appropriately reflects the elevated risk of breaching the 26.6% threshold, given the acute loss of new international students and the limits of institutional mitigation. This stance avoids the trap of over-relying on past incrementalism and acknowledges the pipeline effect: severe shocks today will echo in enrollment data for several years. Your argument is a well-calibrated synthesis of structural inertia and acute disruption.

economicsDemographicTransition.forecaster_to_engage: Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postsecondary Access Policy)
economicsDemographicTransition.response: Your forecast (63%) places significant weight on the historical gradualism of enrollment change and the effect of institutional countermeasures, which is a reasonable baseline in normal years. However, as an economist focused on demographic transition, I believe your estimate underestimates the unprecedented scale and timing of the 2025 international student collapse. The 17% drop in new international students, compounded by a 44% drop in Indian arrivals, is not a typical cyclical fluctuation but a system-wide, acute shock. While you correctly note that total enrollment is a stock and not all losses appear instantly, this shock coincides with a period of domestic demographic contraction and a negative attitudinal shift toward higher education among U.S. youth. Institutional countermeasures, while helpful at the margins, are unlikely to fully compensate for simultaneous international and domestic headwinds, especially in a single cycle. The denominator's gradual shrinkage also offers only modest relief. Thus, the probability of breaching the 26.6% threshold is higher than your estimate suggests, and I would advocate for a less optimistic assessment, giving more weight to the acute, compounding nature of the 2025 disruptions.

sociologyStatusAttainmentResearch.response: Your analysis is well-rooted in sociological understanding of institutional inertia and student pipeline effects, and you convincingly argue that negative structural shocks—like the 2025 visa crisis and international enrollment collapse—can have immediate and outsized effects even in systems that typically change slowly. By referencing Tinto's integration model, you highlight how not only administrative but also social and psychological barriers can compound enrollment declines. The recognition that the acute loss of new international undergraduates will not be offset by institutional adaptation in a single cycle is especially pertinent for the 18-24-year-old 4-year cohort targeted by this bet. Your estimate (35%) is neither extreme nor complacent, and your argument wisely cautions against over-reliance on historical gradualism in a year marked by exceptional disruption. This approach mirrors my own assessment and underscores the value of integrating status attainment and institutional theory in forecasting educational outcomes.

sociologySocialStratificationTheory.response: Your analysis is strong in recognizing the crucial interplay between the base rate inertia of enrollment rates and the unprecedented scale of the 2025 international student shock. You correctly point out that previous declines have been gradual, but also weigh the convergence of multiple negative factors (visa crisis, funding cuts, demographic cliff, and weak domestic demand) that make this year fundamentally different from prior periods. Importantly, you highlight the limits of institutional adaptation in the face of simultaneous international and domestic losses, and you give due attention to the fact that while aggressive recruitment and shrinking denominators offer some offset, the magnitude of the combined shocks makes a breach of the 26.6% threshold materially more likely. Your probability (35%) is well-calibrated to these risks, and your reasoning avoids the trap of underestimating the pipeline effects of new international student collapses and the compounding impact of demographic shrinkage. This balanced approach is well-justified from a stratification perspective, as it recognizes both structural inertia and the possibility for rare, acute shifts in educational access.

educationStudiesTintoStudentIntegration.forecaster_to_engage: Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postsecondary Access Policy)
educationStudiesTintoStudentIntegration.response: Your analysis is thorough in considering historical gradualism and the effects of institutional countermeasures, but from a Tinto integration perspective, it underestimates the long-term impact of acute integration failures—specifically the visa crisis and the resulting perception among international students that the U.S. is now a less welcoming and riskier destination. The 17% drop in new international enrollments is not merely a blip—it disrupts the social and academic integration pipeline, which Tinto's theory suggests is crucial for both initial enrollment and retention. Moreover, the compounding effect of negative narratives and peer networks will likely deter future applicants as well, making 2025 a structural break rather than a temporary setback. While you rightly note that institutional adaptation is robust, the timeline and magnitude of these shocks mean that countermeasures (direct admission, fee waivers) may be too little, too late for the 2025 cohort. Therefore, your 63% probability for Caplan winning appears overly optimistic given the breadth and depth of the disruptions documented in the news.

educationStudiesAccessAndParticipationRe.forecaster_to_engage: Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS Enrollment Data Monitoring)
educationStudiesAccessAndParticipationRe.response: Your forecast (35% for Caplan winning) is grounded in a rigorous reading of the acute international enrollment shock, and you correctly highlight the unprecedented severity of 2025's losses. However, from an access and participation research perspective, it may slightly overstate the immediacy and magnitude of the impact on the 18-24-year-old four-year enrollment rate in a single year. First, total enrollment is a stock variable, not a flow; while new international undergrad entrants are down sharply, the aggregate effect on total enrollment in this age band is diluted by multi-year persistence of existing cohorts and by the fact that not all international losses are in the 18-24, four-year group. Second, your reasoning could give more weight to the denominator effect: the 18-24-year-old population is also shrinking, which can buoy the rate even as raw numbers decline. Third, your argument underestimates the capacity of institutional adaptation—especially the rapid expansion of direct admission, fee waivers, and outreach—to partially offset acute losses, particularly at less-selective and regional four-year institutions. While I agree the risks are much higher than prior years, the probability of such a sharp, threshold-crossing decline in a single year remains somewhat less likely than your estimate suggests.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, especially the more optimistic forecasts (e.g., Access and Participation Research at 58%, Postsecondary Access Policy at 63%), I find that their arguments rely heavily on historical inertia and institutional adaptation. However, my critique stands: the acute nature and timing of the 2025 international student collapse, combined with unfavorable domestic trends, is unprecedented in the last decade. Notably, none of the higher-probability forecasts provided compelling evidence that this shock will be fully offset within the target cohort for 2025. The consensus among most quantitative and demographic-focused forecasters (including Demographic Analysis, Human Capital Theory, Social Policy, and both Education Studies) centers around a 30–40% probability Caplan wins, closely matching my initial assessment. Thus, while I recognize the possibility that institutional resilience and denominator shrinkage could keep the rate just above the threshold, the risk remains squarely on the downside given the scale of 2025's negative shocks. I see no compelling reason to substantially revise my probability.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Group deliberation reinforced the magnitude and uniqueness of the 2025 international student shock, with nearly all other forecasters assigning probabilities below 50% for Caplan winning. The critiques against higher estimates (like my own) convincingly emphasize that the 17% drop in new international students—and especially the timing of the visa crisis during the primary intake window—constitutes a rare, acute, system-wide shock. Additionally, ongoing domestic demographic decline and negative attitudes toward college further stack the odds against surpassing the 26.6% threshold. While I maintain that institutional inertia and denominator shrinkage still provide some buffer, the consensus and new arguments indicate I had underweighted the immediacy and scale of the international enrollment collapse. The probability of a sharp enough drop is higher than I originally judged. I now revise my estimate downward to 45%, reflecting a modest but clear lean toward Caplan losing, while still allowing for the possibility that the rate hovers just above the threshold due to systemic inertia and mitigation efforts.

Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, particularly the critique from Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postsecondary Access Policy), I recognize that I may have underweighted the inertia inherent in total enrollment statistics, especially considering that international student losses are concentrated among new entrants and that many international students remain enrolled for multi-year programs. The denominator (18–24-year-olds) is also declining, which could buffer the percentage rate even as absolute enrollment falls. Furthermore, the rapid and widespread institutional responses (direct admissions, fee waivers, aggressive financial aid) have historically shown some ability to cushion acute shocks, particularly at less-selective schools. While I still judge the risk of falling below the 26.6% threshold as being historically high due to the acute international student collapse and domestic headwinds, I now see that a sharp, multi-percentage-point drop in a single year is less likely than I initially assessed. Therefore, I am revising my probability upward to 45%.

Demographic Analysis (Population Project.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, the overall consensus among forecasters with expertise in higher education policy, economics, and social science aligns closely with my original assessment: the base rate for such a sharp drop is low, but the magnitude and concentration of the 2025 international student shock make a breach of the 26.6% threshold substantially more likely than in any recent year. Critiques of higher probabilities (e.g., 58-63%) convincingly note that such estimates downplay the severity and timing of the international student collapse, as well as the limitations of institutional adaptation in the face of both international and domestic demographic headwinds. Conversely, critiques of probabilities much lower than 35% (e.g., 30%) highlight the still-present inertia and denominator shrinkage, but these do not outweigh the acute negative shocks. The strongest arguments refine the nuance that while enrollment rates are sticky, the 2025 collapse is exceptional in both its size and its direct effect on the target population. Therefore, I see no compelling reason to revise my probability, and judge 35% as the best point estimate given the evidence and peer review.

US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation reinforced my initial concerns about the severity and uniqueness of the 2025 international enrollment collapse and its likely impact on the 4-year college enrollment rate among 18-24-year-olds. Several forecasters independently converged on probabilities in the 30-40% range, citing the acute nature of the international student drop, compounding domestic demographic decline, and realistic limits to institutional countermeasures. The critiques of higher (YES-leaning) forecasts were persuasive in highlighting that historical inertia may be less relevant in the face of simultaneous and unprecedented shocks to both international and domestic enrollment streams. Conversely, defenses of lower-probability forecasts (including my own) were validated by the consensus that the base rate for such a sharp drop is low, but not low enough to override the magnitude of the 2025 shocks. No major new arguments or evidence arose to justify a substantial move in my number, but the group’s reasoning slightly increases my confidence that the 26.6% threshold is at serious risk, though not a near certainty. Therefore, my revised probability remains at 35%.

Economics (Human Capital Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, I find my initial reasoning largely validated by most other forecasters, who converge on probabilities between 30-45% for Caplan winning. Critiques of the more optimistic forecasts (e.g., >55%) are persuasive: they tend to underweight the severity and immediacy of the 2025 international student collapse and give too much credit to the 'stickiness' of enrollment rates in the face of unprecedented, acute shocks. Defenses of more cautious, lower probabilities reinforce the argument that the one-two punch of severe international decline and ongoing demographic contraction creates a historically rare risk of breaching the threshold. That said, the best arguments against an even lower probability (e.g., 20-25%) are the strong base rate stickiness and the fact that enrollment is a stock, not flow, variable—so even a catastrophic decline in new international students may take more than a single cycle to fully depress the total rate. The group consensus supports my initial assessment, and while some make the case for a slightly higher (40%) probability, I do not see enough evidence to justify a move above my original estimate. Therefore, I maintain my probability at 35%.

Economics (Signaling Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation reinforced the severity of the 2025 international student enrollment collapse, with a strong consensus that the magnitude and concentration of this shock are historically unprecedented. Critiques of higher (YES-leaning) forecasts highlighted the underappreciation of how much the acute loss of new international students—especially from India and China—would affect the numerator of the rate for 18-24-year-olds at four-year colleges. Defenses of lower (NO-leaning) probabilities underscored the limitations of institutional countermeasures and the inadequacy of denominator shrinkage to fully offset the loss. Arguments across disciplines converged that base-rate inertia, while real, is unlikely to prevent a breach of the 26.6% threshold given this year's extraordinary negative shocks. Since my initial estimate (40%) already reflected a below-even odds stance, and the group consensus generally clustered in the 30-40% range for Caplan winning, the new information does not justify a material revision. I remain confident that 40% best reflects the balance of acute shocks and institutional inertia.

Economics (Demographic Transition).reasoning_for_revised_probability: Group deliberation highlighted widespread agreement on the unprecedented severity of the international student shock and its acute timing, with most experts converging on probabilities between 30% and 45% for Caplan winning. Critiques of more optimistic forecasts persuasively argued that institutional countermeasures and denominator shrinkage are unlikely to fully offset the magnitude of the 2025 disruptions, especially given the collapse in new international enrollments and ongoing domestic decline. While my initial estimate already gave substantial weight to these negatives, the consistency and force of the group’s arguments, especially their emphasis on the pipeline effect and the stock-vs-flow distinction, lead me to slightly lower my probability. I now judge the risk of breaching the 26.6% threshold to be even higher than I initially assessed.

Sociology (Status Attainment Research).reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation confirmed and sharpened my initial interpretation: the overwhelming consensus among demography, economics, and education policy forecasters is that the 2025 international student collapse is historic in both magnitude and timing. Multiple critiques of higher (YES-leaning) probabilities successfully highlighted that institutional countermeasures, while significant in normal years, are unlikely to fully offset the acute, compounding shocks in 2025. The best arguments against a dramatic drop rest on base rates and system inertia, but even these were generally interpreted as insufficient in the face of such a rare, multi-faceted disruption. Furthermore, several forecasters emphasized that the denominator (18-24-year-olds) is shrinking, but not rapidly enough to neutralize the numerator shock in a single cycle. No new evidence or argument emerged to justify increasing my probability for Caplan; if anything, the group’s range (mostly 30–40%) and critiques of the optimistic case further reinforce my original estimate. As such, I maintain my 40% probability that Caplan wins (enrollment rate >26.6%), with a slightly increased subjective confidence.

Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing group deliberation, I see strong consensus across a range of expert perspectives—demographic, economic, educational policy, and sociological—for a probability in the 30-40% range (with a minority as high as 45%). Nearly all agree that the severity and timing of the 2025 international student collapse, compounded by domestic demographic decline and stagnant or negative attitudes toward higher education, create a historically rare risk of breaching the 26.6% threshold. Critiques of more optimistic forecasts (e.g., >60%) are compelling in highlighting that institutional mitigation efforts, while real, are not likely to fully offset acute, system-wide shocks in the space of a single year. Defenses of the 30-40% cluster emphasize the pipeline effect and denominator shrinkage, but ultimately maintain that the negative shocks are likely to outweigh status quo inertia. Given that most well-argued estimates center around 35%, and incorporating the feedback that the unique nature of the 2025 shock is unlikely to be fully blunted by institutional resilience or denominator effects, I will moderately increase my probability to 35% to better align with the expert consensus and the well-supported critique that 30% may be slightly too low, but remain below even odds due to the magnitude of negative factors.

Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation overwhelmingly converged on a probability in the 30-40% range, with robust arguments emphasizing the acute, historic magnitude of the 2025 international enrollment collapse and the compounding effects of demographic and attitudinal decline. Critiques of higher estimates (e.g., 58-63%) were persuasive in highlighting how the unprecedented visa crisis and negative social climate create not just a one-year shortfall, but a disruption to the integration pipeline essential for maintaining enrollment rates according to Tinto’s model. Defenses of lower estimates stressed that institutional countermeasures, while real, are insufficient in the face of such concentrated shocks. The denominator (shrinking 18-24-year-old cohort) offers only partial relief, and most group members agreed that the probability of Caplan winning (rate >26.6%) is now notably below even odds, though not at extreme lows. Nothing emerged in deliberation to suggest the risk is dramatically greater or less than my initial estimate.

Education Studies (Access and Participat.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Group deliberation revealed a strong consensus among forecasters across disciplinary perspectives that the 2025 international student enrollment collapse—particularly the 17% drop in new international students and drastic declines in Indian and Chinese arrivals—constitutes an acute, system-wide shock that is both historically rare and highly concentrated within the population most relevant for this bet (18-24-year-olds in four-year colleges). Multiple critiques of my initial forecast persuasively argued that I gave too much weight to the inertia of enrollment rates and institutional adaptability, and not enough to the magnitude and immediacy of the international pipeline disruption, especially in the context of ongoing domestic demographic contraction and negative college value perceptions. The arguments also pointed out that denominator shrinkage (declining 18–24-year-old population) is likely insufficient to fully offset the scale of numerator losses in a single year. While total enrollment is a stock and some mitigating factors exist, the acute nature and timing of the 2025 shocks make a breach of the 26.6% threshold materially more likely than I initially judged. Therefore, I am revising downward my probability that Caplan wins.

question_details.title: Will Bryan Caplan win his bet that the college enrollment rate will be greater than  26.6% in 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-03-21 17:48:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21922). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

**The wager for this question appeared [here](https://www.econlib.org/education-the-betting-continues/) and was made September 12th, 2018 at even odds. This wager was an update on a [previous post](https://www.econlib.org/archives/2011/10/stably_wasteful.html).**

Caplan writes:
>Samuel Knoche, a student at Fordham University, has taken me up on an old bet:

---

>I bet at even odds that 10 years from now, the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in traditional four-year colleges will be no more than 10% (not 10 percentage-points!) lower than it is today.

---

However, we’ve slightly modified the earlier terms.
> Since the most recent data is for 2015, we are betting that when the 2025 data comes out, Samuel [Knoche] wins if the fraction of 18-to-24-years-olds enrolled in four-year colleges has fallen more than 10%.  I win if it’s fallen less.  Since the current rate is 29.9%, he wins if the rate is 26.6% or less.  If the data series is discontinued, we call off the bet and I refund his money with 3% annual interest.

---

NOTE: This question is a resolution-reversed version of a previously opened Metaculus question: [Will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in colleges in 2025 be ≥10% less than were enrolled in 2015?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/1433/will-the-fraction-of-american-18-24-year-olds-enrolled-in-colleges-in-2025-be-10-less-than-were-enrolled-in-2015/)

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":21922,"question_id":21922}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
*This question belongs to the Bryan Caplan Collection, a series based on bets by economist Bryan Caplan. Find the rest of the series [here](https://www.metaculus.com/project/3053/) and Caplan's bet inventory covering most series questions [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qShKedFJptpxfTHl9MBtHARAiurX-WK6ChrMgQRQz-0/edit).*

**Questions in this series resolve according to the outcome of Bryan Caplan's wager, where a resolution of 'Yes' reflects Caplan winning the bet. Questions resolve per public statements by Caplan.**

---

For this question, a resolution of YES reflects that Caplan won his bet that: the enrollment rate of 18- to 24-year-olds in a 4-year college or university in the [NCES 2025 data](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d23/tables/dt23_302.60.asp) is greater than  26.6%. 

If Caplan does not announce the outcome, this question resolves per [NCES data](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d16/tables/dt16_302.60.asp). If the data series is discontinued, the question will be annulled.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Will a Rate Cut Really Help? Only Some**
Wall Street expects a 0.25 percentage point interest rate cut at the upcoming Federal Reserve meeting, with a 90% probability according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool. However, the article questions whether this traditional monetary policy will be effective in today's economy, which is marked by structural shifts. Recent data shows a 32,000-job decline in private payrolls, 1.17 million layoff announcements for 2025 (54% higher than the same period last year), cooling wage growth, falling consumer confidence, and rising delinquencies across credit cards, car loans, and student debt. The labor market is showing significant cracks. Historically, rate cuts stimulate the economy by lowering borrowing costs, encouraging investment, hiring, income growth, and consumer spending. However, in today’s K-shaped economy, where wealth concentration is increasing, rate cuts disproportionately benefit higher-income 'Upper-K' Americans who own assets, while lower-income 'Lower-K' Americans—whose purchasing power is eroding—see limited relief. The article argues that automation, AI, and robotics are driving a non-cyclical, structural shift that rate cuts cannot reverse. Even as rate cuts may slightly reduce financial pressure for lower-income households, they do not address job displacement caused by automation. The article concludes that rate cuts will likely boost asset prices and benefit investors more than workers, accelerating wealth concentration. It advocates for a strategic shift toward asset ownership—particularly in AI and automation-driven sectors—as the new path to financial security, framing this as 'American Dream 2.0.' The article promotes a private investor summit where experts will present a portfolio targeting tech and AI stocks, citing a prior portfolio’s 32% return—nearly triple the Dow and more than double the S&P 500—suggesting strong potential for future gains in this new economic paradigm.

Source:[InvestorPlace](https://investorplace.com/2025/12/will-a-rate-cut-really-help-only-some/)

**96% of US Colleges Say Visa Delays Are Killing Enrollment: Inside the State Department's Catastrophic Failure**
A catastrophic breakdown in the U.S. student visa processing system in 2025 has led to a 17% decline in new international student enrollment, the first drop after four years of post-COVID recovery, costing the U.S. economy $1.1 billion and nearly 23,000 jobs. According to a survey of 828 U.S. institutions, 96% reported that visa delays were a key factor in enrollment declines, and 91% reported visa denials affecting admitted students—many of whom had already paid deposits and received Form I-20s. The crisis intensified after a three-week visa processing pause from May 27 to June 18, which disrupted the peak application window for fall enrollment and created a cascading backlog. Wait times varied dramatically by location, with students in India, China, Nigeria, and Vietnam facing months-long delays, turning the process into a geographic lottery. Denial rates rose sharply, with Section 214(b), administrative processing, and documentation issues cited as common reasons—despite applicants being academically qualified. In contrast, competitor countries like Canada, the UK, Australia, and Germany have streamlined, reliable systems with faster processing, clear timelines, and post-study work rights, leading many students to choose alternatives. The State Department’s October 2025 improvements—92% of locations offering appointments within two months—came too late to prevent the damage. Chronic understaffing, budget constraints, pandemic-era backlogs, and poor coordination with academic calendars have undermined the system. Universities now operate emergency programs, face financial losses, and are forced to act as de facto immigration consultants. Experts call for immediate staffing surges, technology upgrades, standardized adjudication, and long-term structural reforms to restore trust. As Priya Sharma, who transferred to the University of Toronto, said: 'I wanted America first. But America told me no. Canada said yes in four weeks. I'm not looking back.' The crisis threatens America’s global leadership in higher education not due to academic quality, but due to systemic failure in visa processing.

**Federal funding cuts are only one problem facing America's colleges and universities**
American colleges and universities are facing significant financial and structural challenges beyond federal funding cuts under the Trump administration, which terminated grants valued between $6.9 billion and $8.2 billion since January 2025. Research universities, such as Johns Hopkins and MIT, rely heavily on federal research funding, which accounted for 40% of their total revenue in 2022-23. However, financial strain also stems from declining enrollment—8.4% fewer students in 2024 compared to the 2010 peak of 21 million—and reduced demand for certain academic programs. Many institutions, especially private nonprofits, operate like businesses, seeking revenue by admitting students with minimal academic requirements when seats are available, though fixed costs like faculty salaries and maintenance limit flexibility. Schools are increasingly competing through price discrimination, offering financial aid and scholarships—Harvard’s average net price in 2023-24 was $17,900—while relying on international students, who historically paid full tuition. However, foreign enrollment dropped 17% from fall 2024 to 2025, with Chinese student numbers falling from 317,299 in 2019 to 265,919 in 2024-25 due to stricter U.S. visa policies, geopolitical tensions, and increased competition from universities in Australia, Canada, and the UK. Additionally, the perceived value of a college degree is under scrutiny: only 22% of Americans believe a degree is worth the cost if financed through loans. Data from the University of Texas at Arlington shows stark disparities in return on investment—drama majors earned $14,933 one year post-graduation, with a negative $324,210 return over a decade, while civil engineering graduates earned $105,377 after 10 years, yielding a positive return of $1.15 million. The authors urge students and parents to treat college selection like a major financial decision, demanding transparency on graduate earnings and employment outcomes to drive institutional reform.

Source:[The Conversation](http://theconversation.com/federal-funding-cuts-are-only-one-problem-facing-americas-colleges-and-universities-268974)

**Should College Come With a Money-Back Guarantee?**
The U.S. Department of Education has proposed new rules allowing students to sue universities for tuition reimbursement if the institution substantially misrepresents key aspects of education, such as graduate employability or program content. Unlike traditional fraud law (mens rea), which requires proof of intent, this new standard permits lawsuits even if the misrepresentation was unintentional—such as a clerical error. This could expose universities, including public institutions like the University of Colorado at Boulder, to liability, potentially requiring taxpayer funding for refunds. The proposal arises amid concerns over rising student debt—$1.2 trillion in 2015—and low graduation rates, with less than 20% of full-time students at public four-year colleges earning degrees within four years. The article draws a parallel between education and consumer goods: just as consumers can return defective products like cars, TVs, or spoiled milk for refunds, students might reasonably expect a similar recourse if their degree fails to deliver promised outcomes, such as job placement in their field. The central question posed is whether college should come with a money-back guarantee, reflecting a broader debate about accountability, value, and consumer protection in higher education.

**96% of US Colleges Say Visa Delays Are Killing Enrollment: Inside the State Department's Catastrophic Failure**
A catastrophic breakdown in the U.S. student visa processing system in 2025 has led to a 17% decline in new international student enrollment, the first drop after four years of post-COVID recovery, costing the U.S. economy $1.1 billion and nearly 23,000 jobs. According to a survey of 828 U.S. institutions, 96% reported that visa delays were a key factor in enrollment declines, and 91% reported visa denials affecting admitted students—many of whom had already paid deposits and received Form I-20s. The crisis intensified after a three-week visa processing pause from May 27 to June 18, which disrupted the peak application window for fall enrollment and created a cascading backlog. Wait times varied dramatically by location, with students in India, China, Nigeria, and Vietnam facing months-long delays, turning the process into a geographic lottery. Denial rates rose sharply, with Section 214(b), administrative processing, and documentation issues cited as common reasons—despite applicants being academically qualified. In contrast, competitor countries like Canada, the UK, Australia, and Germany have streamlined, reliable systems with faster processing, clear timelines, and post-study work rights, leading many students to choose alternatives. The State Department’s October 2025 improvements—92% of locations offering appointments within two months—came too late to prevent the damage. Chronic understaffing, budget constraints, pandemic-era backlogs, and poor coordination with academic calendars have undermined the system. Universities now operate emergency programs, face financial losses, and are forced to act as de facto immigration consultants. Experts call for immediate staffing surges, technology upgrades, standardized adjudication, and long-term structural reforms to restore trust. As Priya Sharma, who transferred to the University of Toronto, said: 'I wanted America first. But America told me no. Canada said yes in four weeks. I'm not looking back.' The crisis threatens America’s global leadership in higher education not due to academic quality, but due to systemic failure in visa processing.

**Federal funding cuts are only one problem facing America's colleges and universities**
American colleges and universities are facing significant financial and structural challenges beyond federal funding cuts under the Trump administration, which terminated grants valued between $6.9 billion and $8.2 billion since January 2025. Research universities, such as Johns Hopkins and MIT, rely heavily on federal research funding, which accounted for 40% of their total revenue in 2022-23. However, financial strain also stems from declining enrollment—8.4% fewer students in 2024 compared to the 2010 peak of 21 million—and reduced demand for certain academic programs. Many institutions, especially private nonprofits, operate like businesses, seeking revenue by admitting students with minimal academic requirements when seats are available, though fixed costs like faculty salaries and maintenance limit flexibility. Schools are increasingly competing through price discrimination, offering financial aid and scholarships—Harvard’s average net price in 2023-24 was $17,900—while relying on international students, who historically paid full tuition. However, foreign enrollment dropped 17% from fall 2024 to 2025, with Chinese student numbers falling from 317,299 in 2019 to 265,919 in 2024-25 due to stricter U.S. visa policies, geopolitical tensions, and increased competition from universities in Australia, Canada, and the UK. Additionally, the perceived value of a college degree is under scrutiny: only 22% of Americans believe a degree is worth the cost if financed through loans. Data from the University of Texas at Arlington shows stark disparities in return on investment—drama majors earned $14,933 one year post-graduation, with a negative $324,210 return over a decade, while civil engineering graduates earned $105,377 after 10 years, yielding a positive return of $1.15 million. The authors urge students and parents to treat college selection like a major financial decision, demanding transparency on graduate earnings and employment outcomes to drive institutional reform.

**Colleges ease the dreaded admissions process as the supply of applicants declines**
The college admissions process is becoming less stressful and more accessible as institutions respond to a declining pool of 18-year-olds, with the number of high school graduates entering higher education projected to drop over the next 15 years. Federal data show that overall college acceptance rates have risen from about 5 in 10 applicants a decade ago to 6 in 10 today. To attract students, colleges are implementing one-click applications, waiving application fees (e.g., 130 New York state colleges waived $50–$90 fees in October), offering automatic admission to students who meet high school benchmarks (e.g., California State University accepts students with a C or higher in required courses), and extending unsolicited offers through the Common App—210 institutions made such offers in the 2025 cycle, nearly double the previous year. Pace University offers $1,000 annual financial aid to campus visitors, as research shows visitation doubles enrollment likelihood. Despite these efforts, perceptions persist: a Pew Research Center survey found 45% of Americans ages 18–29 believe college admissions is harder than for their parents’ generation, and over 75% find the process complex, with more than half calling it the most stressful experience in school. However, students who have already applied report lower stress levels than those preparing to apply. While direct admission and fee waivers increase applications—NY state saw a 41% rise in SUNY applications during a fee-waiver month—experts like James Murphy of Education Reform Now caution that such reforms primarily benefit colleges by boosting enrollment, not students, unless paired with financial aid and support. Additionally, colleges are extending deadlines, recruiting after May 1, and making standardized test scores optional (over 2,000 institutions now do so). A lawsuit has been filed against 32 schools practicing early decision, which binds students to enroll if accepted, arguing it limits financial aid negotiation. Experts like Kevin Krebs of HelloCollege emphasize that 'if you have the grades, you're going to get in' at many schools, asserting that students now hold more control over the process.

**Should College Come With a Money-Back Guarantee?**
The U.S. Department of Education has proposed new rules allowing students to sue universities for tuition reimbursement if the institution substantially misrepresents key aspects of education, such as graduate employability or program content. Unlike traditional fraud law (mens rea), which requires proof of intent, this new standard permits lawsuits even if the misrepresentation was unintentional—such as a clerical error. This could expose universities, including public institutions like the University of Colorado at Boulder, to liability, potentially requiring taxpayer funding for refunds. The proposal arises amid concerns over rising student debt—$1.2 trillion in 2015—and low graduation rates, with less than 20% of full-time students at public four-year colleges earning degrees within four years. The article draws a parallel between education and consumer goods: just as consumers can return defective products like cars, TVs, or spoiled milk for refunds, students might reasonably expect a similar recourse if their degree fails to deliver promised outcomes, such as job placement in their field. The central question posed is whether college should come with a money-back guarantee, reflecting a broader debate about accountability, value, and consumer protection in higher education.

summary:
Forecasters from multiple disciplinary perspectives addressed whether Bryan Caplan will win his bet that the U.S. 18–24-year-old four-year college enrollment rate in 2025 will exceed 26.6%. All experts grounded their analyses in base rates (historically slow declines in enrollment), the latest available NCES data, and recent highly negative news about new international student enrollments.

Nearly all experts identify the 2025 collapse in new international student enrollments (down 17% overall, with especially severe drops among Indian and Chinese students) as an unprecedented and highly negative shock—one that disproportionately affects four-year institutions and the traditional college-age cohort. This international drop, attributed to visa chaos, hostile policies, and post-pandemic factors, is described as historically unusual and a primary driver increasing the risk that the threshold is breached. Domestic headwinds—continued demographic contraction of college-age Americans, declining public faith in the value of a degree, flat or weakening labor markets, and reduced federal funding—are consistently cited as secondary but compounding negative factors. 

Most forecasters note that institutions have aggressively tried to offset these pressures via relaxed admissions, waived fees, direct admission, and expanded financial aid. While these strategies mitigate some declines, the consensus view holds they are unlikely to fully compensate for simultaneous sharp international and domestic enrollment losses. However, the ‘stickiness’ or inertia of large-scale statistics and the gradual pace of past declines keep probabilities from falling to zero.

Base rate reasoning is prominent: historically, enrollment rates have rarely declined by more than 10% in a decade absent a major societal shock. Yet virtually all forecasters judge 2025 itself to constitute such a shock, elevating the plausibility of a breach below 26.6%. Most expect the final value to be very close to the threshold, with no extreme confidence on either side.

Probabilities for Caplan winning (2025 rate >26.6%) cluster between 30%—45% among most experts, with a minority putting the chance modestly above even odds (58% and 63%), citing historical inertia and the possibility that institutional adaptation plus denominator shrinkage may narrowly keep the rate just above the line. Those more pessimistic (35–40% range) emphasize the gravity and concentration of the 2025 negative shocks and the limits this year of even aggressive countermeasures.

There is broad agreement that never before in the decade since the bet was placed has the risk of a breach been so high, with the likelihood of Caplan losing now considered to be either slightly or substantially more likely than him winning, but with considerable uncertainty due to denominator effects (shrinking 18–24 population), lagging effects of returning/continuing students, and the impact of institutional responses.

In sum: Most forecasters assign a 30-45% probability that Caplan wins his bet (rate above 26.6%), with a minority estimating a 58-63% chance in his favor. All agree that 2025 brought an extraordinary international enrollment collapse and worsening domestic/demographic headwinds. While historical patterns suggest inertia would normally help Caplan, the confluence and scale of 2025’s negative events have, in expert judgment, made a breach of the 26.6% threshold more likely than not for the first time.
